title: Let's make Live-NFT's with 2500 Art
description: Cardano will struggle with adoption by young people without collaboration from established artists and key amplifiers from arts & culture.

f6_assessments.q0: This project will introduce many new faces to Project Catalyst. There is not a lot of artists on this platform and I am sure they can bring value to the Catalyst community. Artists can contribute to proposals as well as bring their own proposals to Catalyst. Creating more movement and value.
f6_assessments.q1: Team members are established, experienced, well connected to their respective fields and committed to this project. Budget allocation seems sensible and is broken down into identifiable items. They have gone into great detail explaining how they will execute different tasks to make this project a success.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal has defined in great detail it's goals and how it would achieve them. A clear roadmap of these goals on a timeline and having them completed in 3 months. No real risks have been considered, but given the involvement and passion behind the project and their already established community, this project would be quite resilient to any challenges or risks that may come its way.

f6_assessments.q0:
the proposal (as stated) focuses on a group of young people via art discussed by a workshop. 

Since the target group is already limiting the scope of the proposal, also, the main content is limited only to NFT.

It can have an impact on catalyst value onboarding, yet I find it quite limited and narrowly focused.
f6_assessments.q1:
some social media links were provided, yet it is hard to decide, whether their skills match and meet the final outcome. 

I have seen the videos as well, seems legit and okay.
f6_assessments.q2:
the progress:

it can be audited to some extent 

the success: I do not know, how to calculate and measure the catalyst value onboarding. It is always a struggle, when the proposal is in real life, based on meet-ups, workshops, hackathons and such.

f6_assessments.q0:
It will certainly reach new audiences, people who are unlikely to encounter Catalyst otherwise; and it will raise awareness and excitement about one aspect of blockchain technology (NFTs) – but will it really onboard people into Catalyst? Will it get people voting, proposing, or becoming CAs, like the challenge metrics suggest? Unlikely – but then, 'meaningful participation' does look different for different types of community, so maybe this is OK.
The proposal does mention ideas for after the workshop (some lasting resources on social media, and ongoing collaboration with an NFT maker platform on the Cardano blockchain) – if that happened, it could represent genuinely "meaningful engagement", and new participants "providing a contribution that improves Catalyst's ROI."  But that is all after the workshop; so the question of whether the proposal will actually address the challenge (i.e. produce meaningful onboarding of some kind) rests almost entirely on what happens beyond the end of the project itself. As a creative instigator and participatory artist myself, I know that even if numbers attending a one-off workshop are quite high, it doesn't necessarily translate into impact or engagement beyond that. So it's really hard to assess, and the project as it stands could end up just being a cool one-off event. I don't doubt that some productive connections will be formed between the *proposal team* and individuals in Catalyst, and that's brilliant but  it's not the same thing.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal team are well connected with their communities and have a strong network that they are already working with; the budget is fair; there is a clear timeline (with nice integration with the Frei(t)räume conference), and the timeline feels long enough to actually deliver the workshop itself. But it feels like it might be too short to do the background work needed to create much meaningful impact from the workshop, as mentioned above. Also there is no assessment of risk, and no contingency planning for what would happen if anything didn't go to plan, which is a worry. Overall, I can't be confident the project would be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal does not actually suggest any specific audit metrics. But we can audit how many artists attend the workshop;  the bi-weekly community calls will be recorded and analysed by the team, so they will be auditable; social media engagement is auditable; and it would also be possible to audit numbers of any new people contributing to Catalyst or engaging meaningfully with it as a result of the workshop. This would be sufficient to audit the success of the project.

solution: Facilitating NFT 'live-workshop' with established artists from the arts and culture community together with the Catalyst Community.
experience: Board members, creators and artists from SpaceofUrgency, "Frei(t)räume" & "Stadt Nach Acht" conferences in Berlin and UnitedWeStream.
